Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Situation2: They attend a local workshop on updated prescription guidelines to ensure proper patient counseling.
Story: I sat in the back row of the workshop, my phone buzzing insistently in my pocket. The presenter was explaining the latest prescription guidelines, and I knew I needed to pay close attention—patients depended on my knowledge, and I prided myself on giving the best advice. But as a colleague, I was also expected to be responsive, especially today. Leadership had sent a message marked “urgent,” asking me to confirm details for an external partner. I could almost feel the weight of their expectation: a prompt reply, a sign of reliability. My mind raced. If I pulled out my phone, I’d miss crucial updates that could affect patient care. If I ignored the message, I risked letting down my team and possibly jeopardizing an important partnership. My heart pounded as I stared at the unread notification, torn between my commitment to professional growth and my responsibility to my colleagues.
